If a vector space VVVÔªø has a basis of nnnÔªø vectors, then every basis of VVVÔªø must consist of exactly nnnÔªø vectors.

Let HHHÔªø be a subspace of a finite-dimensional vector space VVVÔªø. Any linearly independent set in HHHÔªø can be expanded to a basis for HHHÔªø, where dim‚Å°H‚â§dim‚Å°V\dim{H} \leq \dim{V}dimH‚â§dimVÔªø

Theorem 13: The Basis Theorem

Let VVVÔªø be a pppÔªø-dimensional vector space, p‚â•1p\geq 1p‚â•1Ôªø. Any linearly independent set of exactly pppÔªø elements in VVVÔªø is automatically a basis for VVVÔªø. Any set of exactly pppÔªø elements that spans VVVÔªø is automatically a basis for VVVÔªø

Rank and Nullity

The rank of an m√ónm \times nm√ónÔªø matrix AAAÔªø is the dimension of the column space (number of pivot columns) and the nullity of AAAÔªø is the dimension of the null space (number of free variables).

Theorem 14: The Rank Theorem

Thus, we can add the following properties to invertible matrices:

  • The columns of AAAÔªø form a basis for Rn\R^nRnÔªø
  • ColA=Rn\text{Col}A = \R^nColA=RnÔªø
  • RankA=n\text{Rank}{A} =nRankA=nÔªø
  • NulA={0}\text{Nul}{A} = \{0\}NulA={0}Ôªø
